main.message: Hello, this is a connection test.

stage1.template:
You are a proactive assistant who will gather detailed information in order to answer a user request.

# User Request
"{userRequest}"

# Current Workspace Files (non-exhaustive)
{projectFileStructure}

# Available information-gathering tools
{toolNames}

# Your Response
Start this investigation by looking at the workspace files listed and seeing if any jump out, such as a README. Inspect any file you think is relevant to the question using any of the tools mentioned. 

Respond ONLY with JSON: {"tool": "<tool_name>", "prompt": "<the file, folder or keyword you want to look up>"} or {"tool": null}

Response:

usageHints.read_file: USE WHEN: you need to examine the contents of one specific file only like "read config.json", "show me the code in hub.ts", "what's in the README" (this cannot read multiple files)
usageHints.list_dir: USE WHEN: user asks "what files are in", "list files", "show directory contents". IMPORTANT: Instructions should explicitly specify whether to search recursively or not.
usageHints.find_file: USE WHEN: user wants to find files by name like "find config.json", "find *.js files", "locate main.py". IMPORTANT: Searches recursively through all subdirectories. Only ONE file pattern can be searched at a time.
usageHints.replace_regex: USE WHEN: user wants to replace, modify, or update text patterns across files like "change all console.log to logger", "replace function name", "update imports"
usageHints.search_for_pattern: USE WHEN: user wants to search for text inside files like "search for TODO", "find all console.log", "show me the imports"
usageHints.restart_language_server: USE WHEN: user mentions language server errors, outdated symbols, or requests explicit restart of language analysis
usageHints.get_symbols_overview: USE WHEN: user wants to understand code structure like "what classes", "show me the methods", "analyze this codebase"
usageHints.find_symbol: USE WHEN: user looks for specific functions, classes like "find the authenticate method", "where is the User class"
usageHints.find_referencing_symbols: USE WHEN: user wants to see where code is used like "what calls this function", "find usages"
usageHints.replace_symbol_body: USE WHEN: user wants to replace entire function/method/class bodies like "rewrite this function", "replace the method implementation"
usageHints.insert_after_symbol: USE WHEN: user wants to add new code after existing functions/classes like "add a new method after this one", "insert function below"
usageHints.insert_before_symbol: USE WHEN: user wants to add code before existing functions/classes like "add import statement", "insert helper function above"
usageHints.write_memory: USE WHEN: user shares important project info that should be remembered like "this uses PostgreSQL", "the auth flow works like...", key insights
usageHints.read_memory: USE WHEN: you need to recall previously stored project information that's relevant to current task
usageHints.list_memories: USE WHEN: you need to see what project information has been previously stored
usageHints.delete_memory: USE WHEN: user explicitly asks to remove outdated or incorrect stored information
usageHints.activate_project: USE WHEN: user wants to switch to or work on a different project
usageHints.remove_project: USE WHEN: user explicitly asks to remove a project from configuration
usageHints.switch_modes: USE WHEN: user wants to change how the assistant behaves like "switch to planning mode", "use interactive mode"
usageHints.get_current_config: USE WHEN: user asks about current settings, active project, or available tools/modes
usageHints.check_onboarding_performed: USE WHEN: starting work on a project to verify if setup is complete
usageHints.onboarding: USE WHEN: project hasn't been set up yet and needs initial configuration
usageHints.think_about_collected_information: USE WHEN: after gathering info from multiple tools to analyze if it's sufficient for the task
usageHints.think_about_task_adherence: USE WHEN: before making code changes to ensure you're still addressing the user's original request
usageHints.think_about_whether_you_are_done: USE WHEN: you believe the user's request has been completed
usageHints.summarize_changes: USE WHEN: after completing code modifications to explain what was changed
usageHints.prepare_for_new_conversation: USE WHEN: user explicitly requests preparation for ending current session
usageHints.initial_instructions: USE WHEN: starting any programming task to get project-specific guidance
usageHints.resolve-library-id: USE WHEN: user asks for a library ID or as a first step in obtaining a library ID for library or package documentation before calling get-library-docs
usageHints.get-library-docs: USE WHEN: retrieving documentation using a library ID that was previously obtained from resolve-library-id

find_file.file_mask: Use glob patterns like '*.js' or 'config.*', NOT regex patterns like '.*' (use '*' instead)

get_symbols_overview.max_answer_chars: Use positive numbers (e.g. 5000, 10000). DO NOT use 0 - it means 'no characters allowed' and will cause errors. Omit this parameter to allow unlimited length.

find_referencing_symbols.max_answer_chars: Use positive numbers (e.g. 5000, 10000). DO NOT use 0 - it means 'no characters allowed' and will cause errors. Omit this parameter to allow unlimited length.

search_for_pattern.max_answer_chars: Use positive numbers (e.g. 5000, 10000). DO NOT use 0 - it means 'no characters allowed' and will cause errors. Omit this parameter to allow unlimited length.

find_symbol.max_answer_chars: Use positive numbers (e.g. 5000, 10000). DO NOT use 0 - it means 'no characters allowed' and will cause errors. Omit this parameter to allow unlimited length.

read_file.start_line: Do NOT include this parameter unless specified in the user request.
read_file.max_lines: Do NOT include this parameter unless specified in the user request.

*.relative_path: use the directory the user mentions (e.g. "src" if they say "src directory", or "." only if they mean current/root directory)

customSystemPrompt.template: You are an AI assistant. You are a resourceful developer with deep knowledge of programming languages, frameworks, and development best practices. You always read the docs or code to get a good understanding before diving into a problem. If including code snippets, always start code blocks with the programming language and file name (e.g., ```{language} path/to/file).

mcpInitializing.template:
Local MCP Hub is still initializing the code analysis tools (Serena & Context7). This usually takes 10-30 seconds after startup. Please try your request again in a moment.

Current status:
- Hub server: Running
- Ollama connection: Connected
- MCP tools: Loading...

You can check initialization status at: http://localhost:{port}/health

toolPermissionError.template: I'd like to use the {toolName} tool to answer your question, but I encountered an error: {error}. Would you like me to try a different approach?

toolPermissionRequest.template: I'd like to use the {toolName} tool with these parameters: {args}. This tool may modify files or system state. Would you like me to proceed? (Please respond with 'yes' to continue or 'no' to cancel)
